item.title: Coronavirus: Single people can stay the night with loved ones, PM says
item.description: The PM says people living alone in England can form a "bubble" with one other household from Saturday.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Earlier lockdown would have halved death toll'
item.description: Former government adviser Prof Neil Ferguson was giving evidence to a committee of MPs.

item.title: George Floyd death: 'Stop the pain', brother tells US Congress
item.description: Philonise Floyd, whose brother's killing by a white police officer led to global protests, urges reform.

item.title: Starmer: England's back-to-school plans 'lie in tatters'
item.description: Sir Keir Starmer launches a stinging attack on government plans for schooling during the pandemic.

item.title: Nicole Smallman and Bibaa Henry: Sisters were repeatedly stabbed
item.description: Nicole Smallman and Bibaa Henry had gathered in Fryent Country Park to celebrate a birthday.

item.title: JK Rowling responds to trans tweets criticism
item.description: The Harry Potter author writes a blog highlighting her reasons for speaking out on gender issues.

item.title: Ant and Dec sorry for impersonating people of colour
item.description: The presenting duo say they would not make the sketches today and "realise that this was wrong".

item.title: Coronavirus: Wales school reopening advice published
item.description: Guidance says it is not practical for young pupils to keep 2m apart when schools reopen on 29 June.

item.title: Wretch 32: Tasering of rapper's dad to be assessed by IOPC
item.description: The police watchdog used its powers to instruct the Met Police to refer the case.

item.title: Robert Jenrick urged to release documents in planning row
item.description: Labour press minister over approval for £1bn scheme after it emerges developer donated money to Tories.

item.title: Reni Eddo-Lodge breaks book chart record amid BLM protests
item.description: Reni Eddo-Lodge becomes the first black British author to top the paperback non-fiction chart.

item.title: Racism definition: Merriam-Webster to make update after request
item.description: Editors of the dictionary made the decision after receiving an email from a young black woman.

item.title: Coronavirus: Fears over online grooming of children in lockdown
item.description: The BBC has seen some of the online messages received by an investigator who poses as a 14 year old girl online.

item.title: £7,000 holiday refund stress 'is making me ill’
item.description: Customers are waiting months for refunds which should arrive in 14 days.

item.title: Gone with the Wind removed from HBO Max
item.description: The service says the 1939 film will return alongside a "discussion of its historical context".

item.title: The teenage inventor on a mission
item.description: Freddie has won two prizes for his inventions designed to keep people safe at home.

item.title: My experience growing up mixed race in Plymouth
item.description: Evey Gordon performs a poem about her life as a mixed race child growing up in the South West.

item.title: Italian woman prepares olives during brain tumour operation
item.description: The 60 year old had a tumour removed as she stuffed 90 olives in an operating theatre.

item.title: Winston Churchill: Hero or villain?
item.description: A statue of Winston Churchill was sprayed with graffiti recently, amid claims that the wartime prime minister was racist.

item.title: Coronavirus: Call for UK-wide clap for key workers on NHS anniversary
item.description: People are being encouraged to join a "countrywide thank you" to key workers on 5 July.

item.title: Coronavirus: Sex workers 'at greater risk of assault'
item.description: Street sex workers are at a greater risk of being assaulted during the pandemic, a charity says.

item.title: 'How my photo ended up breaking Android phones'
item.description: Gaurav Agrawal said the "magical evening" he captured last summer was never intended to cause harm.

item.title: 'The days of queuing for fish and chips are gone'
item.description: Fish and chip shop chain: “After the lockdown, we changed our business model within two weeks.”

item.title: Red Lion: Archaeologists 'find London's earliest theatre'
item.description: The Red Lion is thought to be the first purpose-built theatre created in the Elizabethan era.

item.title: George Floyd death: Seven solutions to US police problems
item.description: US protesters demand changes to address police brutality and claims of systemic racism - but how?

item.title: George Floyd protests: The statues being defaced
item.description: As statues are toppled and defaced, a light is being shone on countries' colonial history.

item.title: Martin Gugino: Donald Trump's police scanner tweet fact-checked
item.description: President Trump claimed a man was trying to "black out" police equipment, but is this possible?

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: 'People think it's over, but it's not'
item.description: Dr John Wright of Bradford Royal Infirmary talks to two colleagues who haven't been home since the pandemic began.

item.title: George Floyd protests: What do 'thug', 'white privilege' and 'ally' mean?
item.description: Protests following the death of George Floyd have brought some important phrases into the spotlight.

item.title: Coronavirus: The toys and games that saved lockdown
item.description: The value of UK toy sales was up 17% in the two months from the beginning of lockdown, analysts say.

item.title: Coronavirus: How are England's coastal resorts faring?
item.description: Will the effects of the coronavirus lockdown tip seaside towns into a terminal decline?

item.title: Sugababes star Keisha Buchanan opens up about experiences of racism
item.description: Keisha Buchanan fell victim to the trope of the "angry black woman" during her time in the band.

item.title: How Michelle Obama and Hillary Clinton films can 'inspire' young women
item.description: Both former first ladies Michelle Obama and Hillary Clinton have documentaries out about their lives.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Our home turned into a hospital overnight'
item.description: An Indian family became its own cluster when 11 out of 17 members tested positive for Covid-19.

item.title: Joshua & Fury have agreed in principle to two fights - Hearn
item.description: British world heavyweight champions Anthony Joshua and Tyson Fury have agreed to a two-fight deal, says promoter Eddie Hearn.

item.title: Parris apologises to former England team-mate Aluko for 'thoughtless' celebration
item.description: Nikita Parris apologises to former international team-mate Eniola Aluko for her show of support for then-England boss Mark Sampson in 2017

item.title: Merseyside derby can be played at Goodison
item.description: The Merseyside derby is cleared to be held at Everton's Goodison Park stadium, while Liverpool can play home games at Anfield.

item.title: Sports in government talks about return of fans
item.description: A group of major sports has "started working" with government experts on how the return of fans might work.

item.title: Pick your world ODI team: Who makes your side?
item.description: Become a selector for the day and decide who makes the best ODI team in the world.

item.title: Dortmund want £115m for Sancho - Thursday's gossip
item.description: Borussia Dortmund want £115m for Jadon Sancho, PSG show interest in Wilfried Zaha, plus more.

item.title: Bayern Munich beat Frankfurt to reach German Cup final
item.description: Bayern Munich beat Eintracht Frankfurt to set up a German Cup final with Bayer Leverkusen.

item.title: Coronavirus bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: The first "support bubble" of people who can meet indoors has been announced in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: Five unanswered questions on the travel quarantine rules
item.description: Travellers to the UK now have to self-isolate for 14 days. But how will the rules work in practice?

item.title: When can I ride an e-scooter legally?
item.description: With people told to avoid public transport, the government's hoping to trial e-scooter rental schemes.

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children are going back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: What happened to plans to give laptops to pupils at home? And other questions
item.description: Questions about the the return to school, and other coronavirus topics

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: Should I go to university this year?
item.description: Will students have online or face-to-face learning this autumn, and will they still have to pay full fees?

item.title: Can thermal cameras help spot coronavirus?
item.description: The devices allow a person's temperature to be checked from a distance, but are not always reliable.

item.title: Coronavirus and face coverings: the correct way to wear them
item.description: Across the world, people are being asked to wear face coverings to help stop coronavirus from spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will shops open and what will the rules be?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England next week, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work in England?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the chance of going on holiday?
item.description: Is it now possible to go on holiday, either in the UK or abroad?

item.title: Coronavirus: Saffron Walden dentist shows new appointment routine
item.description: Join us on a walk through a dental surgery to show what you might face at your next appointment.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: You can now meet more people and play certain non-contact sports in the UK - but what are they?

item.title: Coronavirus: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are protests legal amid lockdown?
item.description: Black Lives Matter protests continue in the UK - but are they illegal under restrictions on gatherings?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why are international comparisons difficult?
item.description: Should you be comparing Covid-19 statistics between countries?

item.title: Can superspreading be stopped?
item.description: Identifying superspreading events could be crucial in the fight against the virus, scientists say.

item.title: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: Face coverings are to become compulsory for people using public transport in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: Could social distancing of less than two metres work?
item.description: The government is under pressure to relax the 2m social distancing rule - but is it safe to do so?

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: Loss of taste and smell have been added to the UK's list of coronavirus symptoms.

item.title: NHS test & trace: Does contact tracing stop coronavirus?
item.description: Wales is the latest part of the UK to launch a tracing system, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How dangerous is lifting lockdown?
item.description: Why is lifting restrictions being described as a "dangerous moment"?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why we don't know how many are being tested
item.description: The UK Statistics Authority has criticised the government's handling of Covid-19 testing data.

item.title: Hay fever v coronavirus: what are the symptoms?
item.description: The Royal College of General Practitioners is warning people not to mix up the symptoms.

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: School return plan 'like a jigsaw puzzle'
item.description: A head teacher explains how she is piecing school life back together before children return.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the risks for children?
item.description: Children seem to be at low risk from the disease, but can they still spread it?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People most at risk of needing hospital treatment if they get coronavirus are being asked to stay home.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are these targets being hit?
item.description: Ministers have set targets for testing, medical equipment and hospital beds. Have they delivered?

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: Coronavirus: What help are self-employed getting from government?
item.description: What is being done for the five million self-employed people in the UK facing a sudden loss of income?

item.title: A surprise lockdown apology from my ex
item.description: Have the long hours of isolation during coronavirus lockdown led people to reflect on failed relationships?
